info.game_comments:
1997 Celebrity Jeopardy! game 4.

Law & Order theme music used during the opening.

(Johnny Gilbert: Now entering the studio are today's celebrity guests.  From Law & Order, assistant D.A.'s Jack McCoy and Jamie Ross, and detective Rey Curtis...)

(1, 1).clue: Many women were smitten with him when he played Victor Sifuentes on "L.A. Law"

(2, 1).clue: Galveston, Texas & Sarasota, Florida lie on this famous gulf

(3, 1).clue: Symbolically, a person who starts out poor & becomes wealthy goes "from" these "to riches"

(4, 1).clue: She's the sovereign of Bermuda, Belize & Canada

(5, 1).clue: It's the 7-letter term for any decision reached by a jury

(6, 1).clue: He's first in order of succession to the British throne

(1, 2).clue: Not all TV lawyers do nude scenes, but this Hemingway did on the "Grin and Bare It" episode of "Civil Wars"

(2, 2).clue: NYC's Brooklyn Bridge spans the East River between Brooklyn & this island borough

(3, 2).clue: When someone starts to get riled, he's told to "keep" this garment "on"

(4, 2).clue: In December 1996 Kofi Annan of Ghana was elected secretary-general of this organization

(5, 2).clue: Number of the Constitutional amendment that states you can't be forced to be a witness against yourself

(6, 2).clue: In batting order, this number is the "cleanup" position

(1, 3).clue: He played sleazy lawyer Marty Lang on the 1985 sitcom "Sara", & he's still "Politically Incorrect"

(2, 3).clue: Name shared by Chicago's Great Lake & one of Chicago's major avenues

(3, 3).clue: When you avoid a topic by going around the edge of it, you do this to "the issue"

(4, 3).clue: Now serving as president, this world leader spent 27 years in South African jails

(5, 3).clue: This legal term for murder may be "justifiable" or "excusable" when in self defense

(6, 3).clue: It's the third in order of the "Star Wars" movies

(1, 4).clue: He played E.G. Marshall's lawyer son on "The Defenders" before he played dad to "The Brady Bunch"

(2, 4).clue: In area, this New England state roughly equals Vermont, N.H., Connecticut & Massachusetts combined

(3, 4).clue: Murderous phrase for someone who's all dolled up

(4, 4).clue: This "Paramount Leader" of China died February 19, 1997 at age 92

(5, 4).clue: It's the document that goes through probate

(6, 4).clue: In order of admission to the union, this state is last

(1, 5).clue: This fictional lawyer, whose theme is heard here, won his first case on TV Sept. 21, 1957:

(2, 5).clue: Jefferson City is Missouri's capital & this "City" where the Royals play is Missouri's largest

(3, 5).clue: People who are closely associated for nefarious reasons are said to be "hand in" this

(4, 5).clue: This German chancellor led West Germany before unification in 1990

(5, 5).clue: It's the fee clients pay in advance to an attorney to act on their behalf

(6, 5).clue: A USDA inspector uses this grading level for meat between select & prime

(1, 1).clue: Cathedral in the title of Victor Hugo's novel about Quasimodo

(2, 1).clue: In May 1486, he was received by Queen Isabella, to whom he explained his plan to sail west to Asia

(3, 1).clue: Varieties of this citrus fruit include the blood, Jaffa & Valencia

(4, 1).clue: 12 years after "Diamonds Are Forever", he was back as Bond in 1983's "Never Say Never Again"

(5, 1).clue: America's first of these opened in 1652 to make coins for the Massachusetts Bay colony

(6, 1).clue: Tosca leaps to her death from the parapet of the Castel Sant'Angelo in this Italian capital

(1, 2).clue: A house in the title of an 1851 Nathaniel Hawthorne novel featured 7 of these structures

(2, 2).clue: In 1830 this country declared itself independent from the Netherlands with Brussels as its capital

(3, 2).clue: The Jose Cuervo brand of this liquor dates back to 1758

(4, 2).clue: This author used some of his plots for a proposed late '50s Bond TV series in his book "For Your Eyes Only"

(5, 2).clue: A fin is slang for this bill

(6, 2).clue: The hero of "Fra Gherardo" is charged with heresy & executed this way, like Joan of Arc

(1, 3).clue: In an H.G. Wells novel, a man uses this title object to spend 8 days in the future

(2, 3).clue: Thomas Paine's "The Rights of Man" is a defense of this European country's 1789 revolution

(3, 3).clue: This rather large steak contains both the T-bone & part of the tenderloin

(4, 3).clue: 1 of the 2 women in "On Her Majesty's Secret Service" who were also TV "Avenger"s
(4, 3).correct response: (1 of 2) Diana Rigg or Joanna Lumley

(5, 3).clue: In 1971 President Nixon ended the convertibility of U.S. currency into this metal

(6, 3).clue: In a Bizet opera, this fickle femme fatale is stabbed outside a bull ring, & that's no bull

(1, 4).clue: Whitney Otto's "How to Make an American" one of these includes sewing tips

(2, 4).clue: In order to kill this "Mad Monk", Russian conservatives had to poison, shoot & drown him

(3, 4).clue: In 1992 Coors introduced zomething new & different, this clear malt beverage

(4, 4).clue: 1 of the 3 villains to have their name in a film title
(4, 4).correct response: (1 of 3) Dr. No, Goldfinger or Octopussy

(5, 4).clue: Some banks now have ALMs to let you get one of these for a car 24 hours a day

(6, 4).clue: Distraught that Lt. Pinkerton abandoned her, this Puccini heroine commits hara-kiri

(1, 5).clue: According to the title of an E.M. Forster novel, Lucy Honeychurch wants this from a hotel in Italy

(2, 5).clue: In 1939 Poland was divided almost equally between Germany & this country

(3, 5).clue: Indonesia is famous for this variety of coffee that's often blended with mocha

(4, 5).clue: In his first appearance as Bond in "Live and Let Die", he took on Mr. Big

(5, 5).clue: When he left Disney after just over a year as president, his severance was reportedly over $50 million

(6, 5).clue: In a Donizetti opera, this vengeful female Borgia treats a roomful of dinner guests to poisoned wine

(0, 0).clue: Playwright who penned the famous line, "The first thing we do, let's kill all the lawyers"
